article.text: You can purchase a Redmi Note 6 Pro right now at any Mi Home, Mi Store or Mi Zone. The base model with 32GB storage and 3GB RAM retails for S$289, while the version with 64GB storage and 4GB RAM costs S$329. Slightly more affordable than the Redmi Note 5 Pro at launch.
Design & Display – When Good is No Longer Good Enough

The rear design has been tweaked slightly such that the metal back is surrounded by a plastic frame. But from far, it looks just like its predecessor, the Redmi Note 5. It is by no means a bad design. But after using the glass backed Honor 8X, I feel that Xiaomi could have done better.

The biggest change in design is on the front. The display is a notched 6.26″ 19:9 FHD+ IPS LCD panel. It is bright enough to be seen under sunlight. In fact, it is even brighter than my Redmi 5. Bottom chin is average sized, but the bezels are huge and that notch takes up a lot of space.

Like its predecessor, the Redmi Note 6 Pro is powered by the Snapdragon 636 processor. Thus, we can expect similar performance from it. It is the latest processor of its tier from Qualcomm though, so it wouldn’t be fair to complain about Xiaomi reusing the same processor.

My review unit is the base version with 3GB of RAM. AnTuTu gave it a score of 115158, close to what I got from Redmi Note 5. In Geekbench 4, Redmi Note 6 Pro scored 1299 and 4672 for single-core and multi-core respectively. Again, really close to the Redmi Note 5’s score.

Under actual usage, the Redmi Note 6 fares really well. As mentioned in the video, Rules of Survival runs smoothly even on high graphics. You should be able to play most games on it, though not at max graphics. HD in PUBG Mobile is not supported yet, so the highest graphic setting now is balanced.

On the rear of Redmi Note 6 Pro is a pair of 12MP + 5MP cameras, with specs identical to the local Redmi Note 5. Unfortunately, I do not have a Redmi Note 5 with me now to do a comparison. But like the Redmi Note 5, the Redmi Note 6 Pro does an excellent job under low light, especially for its price.

As we have come to expect from Xiaomi, the Redmi Note 6 Pro’s portrait mode is one of the best in the industry. Most of the time, it does a respectable job at edge detection, even at night. But sometimes it struggles, like in the image below. It failed to blur out part of the van at the bottom of the image.

Probably due to a limitation of the processor, Redmi Note 6 Pro can only record videos up to FHD 30 fps. Videos are vibrant, focusing on subjects is fast and dynamic range is decent for a smartphone. However, stabilization isn’t too great and videos still appear shaky when you walk.
At night, videos turn out blurry, but that is pretty much expected. Most budget phones, even some much costlier phones, are still unable to take good looking night videos yet.

Xiaomi upgraded the Redmi Note 6 Pro’s front camera to a 20MP + 2MP dual camera setup. Under daylight, dynamic range isn’t the best but it is excellent for a selfie camera. With two cameras, you can take portrait mode selfies too. Edges detection for this is not as good as on the rear though.

Under low light, I recommend turning on flash, which uses the display to provide lighting. This is a lot better than having front-facing flashes for 2 reasons. Firstly, it hurts your eyes a lot less. Secondly, due to larger surface area, it lights up your shots really well without making them look unnatural.

You can use the front cameras to unlock your device. It is pretty accurate, but rather slow. Also, there is no lift to wake, so you have to press the power button or double tap the screen before it unlocks. This makes it kind of pointless, considering how fast and reliable the fingerprint scanner is.

As usual, only the right speaker grill houses a speaker. But the earpiece is also used as a speaker, though its sound is pretty tiny. Redmi Note 6 Pro’s speaker is slightly louder than my Redmi 5, but vocals sound warmer and clearer on the Redmi 5. Both sound very good for bottom firing speakers.

Initially, my review unit’s headphone output sounded magical. But upon entering “headphone and audio effect” menu, without me toggling any settings, it went back to sounding normal. This is probably caused by a bug where it uses an audio effect without audio effects being toggled on.

Once that is fixed, audio from Redmi Note 6 Pro’s headphone jack sound similar to the Redmi 5’s, with slightly less boomy bass. It is quite a bit louder though, which is greatly appreciated. It isn’t the best on any smartphone, but for the price, it is among the better ones.
Battery Life – Does Not Feel Like 4000mAh

Like its recent predecessors, Redmi Note 6 Pro comes with a ginormous 4000mAh battery. However, its battery life is nowhere as long as its predecessors. Unfortunately. A single charge could only last me till the end of a day. Screen-on time was a little over 5 hours, with under 2 hours of intensive gaming.
Usage: 1h 14min War Wings, 38min PUBG Mobile, 13min Facebook, 5min Camera (including 45sec video recording), 20min music playback

I did notice that when the battery drops below 20%, performance degrades significantly. Taking photos at night, I had to wait a few seconds for the camera app to load. And even after loading, it would continue to lag every few seconds. Opening and closing of apps also got slower, so charge it early.
There are a few things I would like to see in the next iteration of Xiaomi’s Redmi Note series:
Firstly, I hope Xiaomi would opt for a new design as the current one is pretty stale. Also, the competition is pushing out much nicer looking devices with similar price tags. (E.g. Huawei Nova 3i)

Secondly, it would be nice if the next Redmi Note had an upper Snapdragon 6xx tier processor instead. Maybe the Snapdragon 670? The current Snapdragon 636 is two tiers behind POCOPHONE F1’s Snapdragon 845. Is the S$100 difference enough to justify that? I don’t feel so.

Redmi Note 3, also priced at around S$300+, had a powerful Snapdragon 650. Then, its successor came with a weaker Snapdragon 625, justified by a much lower price tag. Now that the price is back to S$300+, I hope Xiaomi would once again equip the Redmi Note series with a powerful processor.

Lastly, I find it strange that the Redmi Note 6 Pro is still running MIUI 9 despite being a new device. I know that an update is coming, but it is weird that older devices already received MIUI 10 and this hasn’t. I would like to see the next Redmi Note device come with the latest version of MIUI out of the box.
